newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: PAL workers strike, 21 flights scrapped.
newsitem.headline: PAL workers strike, 21 flights scrapped.

text.p: Workers of the Philippine Airlines launched a crippling strike over a pay dispute Wednesday, forcing the airline to cancel eight international and 13 domestic flights, the airline said.

Hundreds of ground crew personnel mounted pickets at Manila's domestic and international airports after President Fidel Ramos refused to intervene in the dispute, despite warnings a walkout might embarrass the country ahead of next month's APEC summit.
Ramos, who had billed the Nov. 25 summit of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum as an event for which "we ... must put on our best face," said he was not a labour arbiter.

The 9,000-strong PAL Employees Association members provide catering and cargo services to several foreign airlines, including Singapore Airlines, Japan Airlines and Cathay, PALEA national secretary Jose Penas III said.
The strike was the third to hit the financially troubled national carrier in two years. PALEA struck twice in 1994, the first stoppage lasting a day and the second nine days.

The three unions are asking for negotiations on a new wage package worth 3.2 billion pesos ($121 million) over the next two years. PAL has rejected the package and instead offered to sell PAL shares worth 477 million pesos ($18.15 million) at five pesos (19 cents) per share to employees.

"The ... airline is cash-strapped and continues to incur losses at approximately 3.0 million pesos ($114,133) a day that could reach more than one billion pesos ($38 million) by the end of the current fiscal year," the company said.
PAL has incurred losses in the past several years due to high operating expenses and cutthroat competition on international routes.
